solution_line_template: He used to use {gallons_per_flush_old}*{flushes_per_day}=<<{gallons_per_flush_old}*{flushes_per_day}={old_daily_usage}>>{old_daily_usage} gallons of water per day.
This means he used {old_daily_usage}*{days_in_june}=<<{old_daily_usage}*{days_in_june}={old_monthly_usage}>>{old_monthly_usage} gallons a month.

His new toilet uses {gallons_per_flush_old}*{water_reduction_percent}=<<{gallons_per_flush_old}*{water_reduction_percent}={water_saved_per_flush}>>{water_saved_per_flush} gallons less water per flush.
So, it only uses {gallons_per_flush_old}-{water_saved_per_flush}=<<{gallons_per_flush_old}-{water_saved_per_flush}={new_gallons_per_flush}>>{new_gallons_per_flush} gallon per flush.
That means he uses {new_gallons_per_flush}*{flushes_per_day}=<<{new_gallons_per_flush}*{flushes_per_day}={new_daily_usage}>>{new_daily_usage} gallons per day.
All in all, it accounts for a total usage of {new_daily_usage}*{days_in_june}=<<{new_daily_usage}*{days_in_june}={new_monthly_usage}>>{new_monthly_usage} gallons.
So, he saved {old_monthly_usage}-{new_monthly_usage}=<<{old_monthly_usage}-{new_monthly_usage}={total_saved_water}>>{total_saved_water} gallons per month.
